title: About
text: Brady Rasso is a passionate Student at the university of Nebraska-Lincoln. He is studying sports media and communications as well as business administration. He works as a student equipment manager with Nebraska athletics. Rasso enjoys going to concerts, playing sports and attending other events.

title: A Tale of two halfs the Nebraska basketball seasson
text:
After the best season in the Fred Hoiberg era, Nebraska basketball entered the year with expectations of returning to the Big Dance. With a newly assembled roster through the transfer portal and key players returning, it seemed like there was no way this team wouldn’t at least make a push for an at-large bid. After a first half that set them up for success the rest of the season, we saw a completely different team down the stretch—one that not only destroyed the Huskers’ tournament dreams but also failed to qualify for the Big Ten tournament. So, what happened between the first and second half of the season?


── Attaching core tidyverse packages ──────────────────────── tidyverse 2.0.0 ──
✔ dplyr     1.1.4     ✔ readr     2.1.5
✔ forcats   1.0.0     ✔ stringr   1.5.1
✔ ggplot2   3.5.1     ✔ tibble    3.2.1
✔ lubridate 1.9.4     ✔ tidyr     1.3.1
✔ purrr     1.0.2     
── Conflicts ────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse_conflicts() ──
✖ dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter()
✖ dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()
ℹ Use the conflicted package (<http://conflicted.r-lib.org/>) to force all conflicts to become errors




Code
iron(
waffle(
  nuwaffle1,
  rows = 3,
  colors = c("#000000", "#E41C38","white")
)+
  labs(
    title = "Nebraska's inconsistency leads to roller coaster season",
    subtitle = "The Huskers looked like two diffrent teams all through out the season",
) +
   theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 16, face = "bold"),
     plot.title.position = "plot"
),
waffle(
  nuwaffle2,
  rows = 3,
  colors = c("#000000", "#E41C38")
)+
  labs(
      x = "1 square = 1 result",
  caption="By: Brady Rasso| Source: hoopR"
 )
)









The Huskers were one of the streakiest teams in the country, with the ability to get hot and torch opponents from three, going on long win streaks—or go ice cold and struggle to take care of lesser competition, leading to multiple consecutive losses. This inconsistency didn’t just apply to game results, but to other aspects of their play as well. Nebraska lived and died by the three a season ago—but how did that carry over?


Code
ggplot() +
 geom_line(
    data = wulogshalf1,
    aes(
      x = game_date,
      y = three_point_field_goal_pct
    ),
    color = "lightgrey"
  ) +
  geom_line(
    data = iowalogshalf1,
    aes(
      x = game_date,
      y = three_point_field_goal_pct
    ),
    color = "lightgrey"
  ) +
  
  geom_line(
    data = illlogshalf1,
    aes(
      x = game_date,
      y = three_point_field_goal_pct
    ),
    color = "lightgrey"
    
  ) +
  geom_line(
    data = iulogshalf1,
    aes(
      x = game_date,
      y = three_point_field_goal_pct
    ),
    color = "lightgrey"
  
  ) +
  geom_line(
    data = marlogshalf1,
    aes(
      x = game_date,
      y = three_point_field_goal_pct
    ),
    color = "lightgrey"

  ) +
  geom_line(
    data = michlogshalf1,
    aes(
      x = game_date,
      y = three_point_field_goal_pct
    ),
    color = "lightgrey"
  ) +
  geom_line(
    data = minnlogshalf1,
    aes(
      x = game_date,
      y = three_point_field_goal_pct
    ),
    color = "lightgrey"
  ) +
  geom_line(
    data = msulogshalf1,
    aes(
      x = game_date,
      y = three_point_field_goal_pct
    ),
    color = "lightgrey"
  ) +
  geom_line(
    data = nwlogshalf1,
    aes(
      x = game_date,
      y = three_point_field_goal_pct
    ),
    color = "lightgrey"
  
  ) +
  geom_line(
    data = osulogshalf1,
    aes(
      x = game_date,
      y = three_point_field_goal_pct
    ),
    color = "lightgrey"
  ) +
  geom_line(
    data = psulogshalf1,
    aes(
      x = game_date,
      y = three_point_field_goal_pct
    ),
    color = "lightgrey"
  ) +
  geom_line(
    data = pulogshalf1,
    aes(
      x = game_date,
      y = three_point_field_goal_pct
    ),
    color = "lightgrey"
)+
  
  geom_line(
    data = rulogshalf1,
    aes(
      x = game_date,
      y = three_point_field_goal_pct
    ),
    color = "lightgrey"
)+
   geom_line(
    data = uclalogshalf1,
    aes(
      x = game_date,
      y = three_point_field_goal_pct
    ),
    color = "lightgrey"
)+
  geom_line(
    data = usclogshalf1,
    aes(
      x = game_date,
      y = three_point_field_goal_pct
    ),
    color = "lightgrey"
)+
  
  geom_line(
    data = wiscologshalf1,
    aes(
      x = game_date,
      y = three_point_field_goal_pct
    ),
    color = "lightgrey"
)+
    geom_line(
    data = oulogshalf1,
    aes(
      x = game_date,
      y = three_point_field_goal_pct
    ),
    color = "lightgrey"
    )+
   geom_line(
    data = nulogshalf1,
    aes(
      x = game_date,
      y = three_point_field_goal_pct
    ),
    color = "#E41C38"
  ) +
geom_text(
  aes(x = as.Date("2025-01-07"), y = 41),
  label = "Nebraska",
  size = 3
) +
   labs(
    y = "Team Three Point Percentage",
    x = "Date",
    title = "Huskers threaten opponents with first half three point shooting ",
    subtitle = "Nebraska's three point shooting was the reason why they won at the beginning of the season",
     caption = "By: Brady Rasso | Source: hoopR"
  ) +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 16, face = "bold"),
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size = 10),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 8),
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
     plot.title.position = "plot"
  ) 









The Huskers were a team that consistently used the three-point shot to beat opponents in the first half of the season. But when the second half came around, how did the Nebraska care over this success?


Code
ggplot() +
  geom_line(
    data = wulogshalf2,
    aes(
      x = game_date,
      y = three_point_field_goal_pct
    ),
    color = "lightgrey"
  ) +
  geom_line(
    data = iowalogshalf2,
    aes(
      x = game_date,
      y = three_point_field_goal_pct
    ),

  ) +
  
  geom_line(
    data = illlogshalf2,
    aes(
      x = game_date,
      y = three_point_field_goal_pct
    ),
    color = "lightgrey"
    
  ) +
  geom_line(
    data = iulogshalf2,
    aes(
      x = game_date,
      y = three_point_field_goal_pct
    ),

  geom_line(

    ),

  ) +

    aes(
      x = game_date,

    ),
    color = "lightgrey"
  ) +
  geom_line(
    data = pulogshalf2,
    aes(
      x = game_date,
      y = three_point_field_goal_pct
    ),
    color = "lightgrey"
)+
  
  geom_line(
    data = rulogshalf2,
    aes(
      x = game_date,
      y = three_point_field_goal_pct
    ),
    color = "lightgrey"
)+
   geom_line(
    data = uclalogshalf2,
    aes(
      x = game_date,
      y = three_point_field_goal_pct
    ),
    color = "lightgrey"
)+
  geom_line(
    data = usclogshalf2,
    aes(
      x = game_date,
      y = three_point_field_goal_pct
    ),
    color = "lightgrey"
)+
  
  geom_line(
    data = wiscologshalf2,
    aes(
      x = game_date,
      y = three_point_field_goal_pct
    ),
    color = "lightgrey"
)+
      geom_line(
    data = oulogshalf2,
    aes(
      x = game_date,
      y = three_point_field_goal_pct
    ),
    color = "grey"
    )+
  
geom_text(
  aes(x = as.Date("2025-03-09"), y = 20),
  label = "Nebraska",
  size = 3
) +
   geom_line(
    data = nulogshalf2,
    aes(
      x = game_date,
      y = three_point_field_goal_pct
    ),
    color = "#E41C38"
  ) +
   labs(
    y = "Team Three Point Percentage",
    x = "Date",
    title = "Nebraksa shoot's theemselves out of mutiple games",
    subtitle = "The Huskers had mutiple games that they underpreformed from behind the arc",
    caption = "By: Brady Rasso | Source: hoopR"
  ) +
theme_minimal() +
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 16, face = "bold"),
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size = 10),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 8),
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
     plot.title.position = "plot"
  )









We could clearly see a drop-off in three-point production from the first half to the second half of the season. And when the moments were the brightest, the shots from behind the arc just weren’t falling. So, with a team that Coach Hoiberg built around size—featuring bigger players at nearly every position—did that size actually translate into rebounding production for the Cornhuskers? More importantly, how did that impact their ability to close out defensive possessions with rebounds or create second-chance opportunities on offense?


Code
ggplot() +
  geom_step(
    data = illlogshalf1,
    aes(x =game_date, y = cumdif),
     color = "lightgrey"
    
)+
    geom_step(
    data = iowalogshalf1,
    aes(x =game_date, y = cumdif),
     color = "lightgrey"
)+
    geom_step(
    data =iulogshalf1,
    aes(x =game_date, y = cumdif),
     color = "lightgrey"
)+
    geom_step(
    data = marlogshalf1,
    aes(x =game_date, y = cumdif),
     color = "lightgrey"
)+
    geom_step(
    data = michlogshalf1,
    aes(x =game_date, y = cumdif),
     color = "lightgrey"
)+
    geom_step(
    data = minnlogshalf1,
    aes(x =game_date, y = cumdif),
     color = "lightgrey"
)+
    geom_step(
    data = msulogshalf1,
    aes(x =game_date, y = cumdif),
     color = "lightgrey"
)+

     color = "lightgrey"

     color = "lightgrey"
)+

    data = psulogshalf1,
    aes(x =game_date, y = cumdif),
     color = "lightgrey"
)+
    geom_step(
    data = pulogshalf1,
    aes(x =game_date, y = cumdif),
     color = "lightgrey"
)+
    geom_step(
    data = rulogshalf1,
    aes(x =game_date, y = cumdif),
     color = "lightgrey"
)+
    geom_step(
    data = uclalogshalf1,
    aes(x =game_date, y = cumdif),
     color = "lightgrey"
)+
    geom_step(
    data = usclogshalf1,
    aes(x =game_date, y = cumdif),
     color = "lightgrey"
)+
    geom_step(
    data = wiscologshalf1,
    aes(x =game_date, y = cumdif),
     color = "lightgrey"
)+
    geom_step(
    data = wulogshalf1,
    aes(x =game_date, y = cumdif),
     color = "lightgrey"
)+
    geom_step(
    data = oulogshalf1,
    aes(x =game_date, y = cumdif),
     color = "lightgrey"
)+
    geom_step(
    data = nulogshalf1,
    aes(x =game_date, y = cumdif),
     color = "#E41C38"
)+
   labs(
    y = "Total rebounds ",
    x = "Date",
    title = "Huskers disapont's when it comes to rebounding ",
    subtitle = "Nebraska size and lack of rebounding talent leaves more to be desired in second half of season",
    caption = "By: Brady Rasso | Source: hoopR"
  ) +
theme_minimal() +
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 16, face = "bold"),
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size = 10),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 8),
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
     plot.title.position = "plot"
  )+
  geom_text(
  aes(x = as.Date("2025-01-07"), y = 500),
  label = "Nebraska",
  size = 3
  )









Nebraska’s size and ability to clean the glass didn’t translate into much production, as they ranked closer to the bottom in total rebounds during the first half of the season. As the Huskers moved into Big Ten play—with more on the line and tournament pressure beginning to mount—the question became clear: How did the Huskers fare on the boards in the second half of the season?


Code
ggplot() +
  geom_step(
    data = illlogshalf2,
    aes(x =game_date, y = cumdif),
     color = "lightgrey"
)+
    geom_step(
    data = iowalogshalf2,
    aes(x =game_date, y = cumdif),
     color = "lightgrey"
)+
    geom_step(
    data =iulogshalf2,
    aes(x =game_date, y = cumdif),
     color = "lightgrey"
)+
    geom_step(
    data = marlogshalf2,
    aes(x =game_date, y = cumdif),
     color = "lightgrey"
)+
    geom_step(
    data = michlogshalf2,
    aes(x =game_date, y = cumdif),
     color = "lightgrey"
)+
    geom_step(
    data = minnlogshalf2,
    aes(x =game_date, y = cumdif),
     color = "lightgrey"
)+
    geom_step(
    data = msulogshalf2,
    aes(x =game_date, y = cumdif),
     color = "lightgrey"

    data = nwlogshalf2,

     color = "lightgrey"

     color = "lightgrey"
)+
    geom_step(
    data = psulogshalf2,
    aes(x =game_date, y = cumdif),
     color = "lightgrey"
)+
    geom_step(
    data = pulogshalf2,
    aes(x =game_date, y = cumdif),
     color = "lightgrey"
)+
    geom_step(
    data = rulogshalf2,
    aes(x =game_date, y = cumdif),
     color = "lightgrey"
)+
    geom_step(
    data = uclalogshalf2,
    aes(x =game_date, y = cumdif),
     color = "lightgrey"
)+
    geom_step(
    data = usclogshalf2,
    aes(x =game_date, y = cumdif),
     color = "lightgrey"
)+
    geom_step(
    data = wiscologshalf2,
    aes(x =game_date, y = cumdif),
     color = "lightgrey"
)+
    geom_step(
    data = wulogshalf2,
    aes(x =game_date, y = cumdif),
     color = "lightgrey"
)+
    geom_step(
    data = oulogshalf2,
    aes(x =game_date, y = cumdif),
     color = "lightgrey"
)+
    geom_step(
    data = nulogshalf2,
    aes(x =game_date, y = cumdif),
     color = "#E41C38"
) +
   labs(
    y = "Total Rebounds",
    x = "Date",
    title = "The Huskers emphasize cleaning the glass",
    subtitle = "Nebraska improves its rebounding struggles in the second half but they remainded average for the season",
    caption = "By: Brady Rasso | Source: hoopR"
  ) +
theme_minimal() +
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 16, face = "bold"),
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size = 10),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 8),
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
     plot.title.position = "plot"
  )+
  geom_text(
  aes(x = as.Date("2025-03-09"), y = 535),
  label = "Nebraska",
  size = 3
  )









We did see some improvement in rebounding during the second half of the season, but at best, Nebraska was average when it came to controlling the glass. And being just average in that area—especially with the size this roster had—isn’t going to cut it when it’s time to win big games. So what does Fred Hoiberg need to do in the portal to make a real run at the Big Dance next year? Find quality shooters—and bring in dominant bigs who can consistently clean the glass.

title: sportsBlog
text:
The collapse of Nebraska basketball’s 2024-2025 season






NCAA


Basketball


Nebraska









Apr 13, 2022


Brady Rasso
